quoteFirst: 291had not Howley emerged from the woods at that moment, and fallen upon their rear. It was then
quoteTime: nearly four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , and the fight was kept up with bravery on both sides until dark, when the enemy retreated, or rather fled, in great disorder, to the woods. During the engagement, and while Rowley was keeping the enemy at bay, Willett succeeded in rallying the militia, who returned to the fight.

quoteFirst: On our arrival the indications of an attack from the enemy were very apparent. They must have anticipated immense slaughter, as no less than a hundred of their ambulances were plainly visible.

quoteFirst: The notion that no sunlight ever gets through and that in the London winter people never see the sun is of course a ridiculous error, circulated no doubt by the jealousy of foreign nations. I have myself seen the sun plainly visible in London, without the aid of glasses, on a November day in broad daylight; and again one night
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: I saw the sun distinctly appear through the clouds. The whole subject of daylight in the London winter is, however, one which belongs rather to the technique of astronomy than to a book of description.
title: My Discovery of England
author: Leacock, Stephen, 1869-1944
